citation.article-title: Exiguobacterium undae sp. nov. and Exiguobacterium antarcticum sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Exiguobacterium antarcticum sp. nov.
Exiguobacterium antarcticum (ant.arc'ti.cum. N.L. gen. n. antarcticum of Antarctica)
Surface colonies on tryptone soy agar (Difco) are 2-3 mm in diameter after 2 days at 25 °C, bright orange, convex, entire and shiny.
Orange pigment does not diffuse into the medium.
Gram-positive, nonspore-forming rods, varying in shape and size of rods from 1.2x3.0 μm in the exponential phase to 0.4x1.5 μm in the stationary phase.
Growth occurs under aerobic and anaerobic conditions in both CASO and BBL medium.
Growth occurs at 20 and 41 °C but not at 45 °C; optimal temperature for growth about 37 °C.
Phenotypic properties are listed in Tables 2 and 3.
The principal isoprenoid quinone is MK-7; MK-6 and MK-8 occur in smaller amounts.
Polar lipids consist of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylethanolamine and an unidentified phospholipid.
Major fatty acids (>5%) are iC13:0, aiC13:0, iC15:0, C16:1ω11c, C16:0 and C18:1ω9c; minor components are listed in Table 1.
Isolated from a microbial mat from Lake Fryxell, Antarctica.
The type strain is strain H2T (=DSM 14480T=CIP 107163T).
